text: If you are somebody for whom you want to make an exponential difference, you want to innovate, you want to create new value where there wasn't, you want to have a legendary career where you could look back on your career and go, you know what? I was part of this and that, and I was on this team, now's the greatest time in history. And what I would say to you is, the future needs you.
speaker: Christopher Lochhead
context: Lenny asks Chris to share his thoughts on the current landscape for creators and entrepreneurs. Chris emphasizes that today is an unprecedented time for innovation and entrepreneurship, encouraging individuals to pursue their passions and make a significant impact. He highlights the importance of working on exponential changes rather than incremental improvements.
text_ko: 당신이 정말로 큰 변화를 만들고 싶고, 혁신하고, 새로운 가치를 창출하고 싶다면, 그리고 나중에 돌아봤을 때 "내가 이 팀의 일원이었고, 저런 일도 했었지"라고 자랑스럽게 말할 수 있는 전설적인 커리어를 원한다면, 지금이 역사상 가장 좋은 시점이에요. 제가 하고 싶은 말은, 미래는 당신이 필요하다는 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你希望创造显著的影响，想要创新，想要在原本没有的地方创造新价值，想要拥有一个传奇的职业生涯，回首往事时能够自豪地说：“我参与了这个和那个，我在这个团队中。”那么，现在是历史上最好的时机。我想对你说的是，未来需要你。
text_es: Si eres alguien que desea hacer una diferencia exponencial, que quiere innovar, crear nuevo valor donde antes no existía, y tener una carrera legendaria de la cual puedas mirar atrás y decir: "Yo formé parte de esto y aquello, y estuve en este equipo", ahora es el mejor momento en la historia. Y lo que te diría es que el futuro te necesita.
key_sentence: Now's the greatest time in history to create new value and have a legendary career.

text: The decision they make is, 'What I'm going to do, is I am going to compete in a market with demand, with a better product/service/brand, maybe a better business model.' And when the world gets my better, the world will beat a path to my door.
speaker: Christopher Lochhead
context: Chris discusses a common mindset among entrepreneurs where they choose to compete in established markets instead of creating new categories. He points out that many mistakenly believe that having a superior product or service will guarantee success. This mindset often leads to fierce competition for a small share of the market rather than innovating and defining a new market space.
vocabulary_highlights: beat a path to my door
text_ko: 그들이 내리는 결정은 '내가 할 일은 수요가 있는 시장에서 더 나은 제품/서비스/브랜드, 어쩌면 더 나은 비즈니스 모델로 경쟁하는 거야.' 라는 거예요. 그리고 세상이 내 더 나은 걸 알게 되면, 사람들이 내 문 앞에 줄을 설 거예요.
text_zh: 他们做出的决定是：“我将要做的是，在有需求的市场中，凭借更好的产品/服务/品牌，甚至可能是更好的商业模式进行竞争。”当世界看到我的优势时，必定会主动找上我。
text_es: La decisión que toman es: "Lo que voy a hacer es competir en un mercado con demanda, con un mejor producto/servicio/marca, tal vez con un mejor modelo de negocio." Y cuando el mundo reconozca mi superioridad, vendrá a buscarme.
key_sentence: A better product/service/brand will make the world beat a path to my door.

text: Nobody legendary ever did that. Not a one. We all know who Bob Marley is. We don't know who the 17th greatest reggae musician or band in the world is.
speaker: Christopher Lochhead
context: Chris argues that the most admired figures in various fields, including business and arts, are those who have created new categories rather than competing within existing ones. He uses Bob Marley as an example of a legendary artist who stands out because he defined his own category, while the lesser-known figures remain largely forgotten. This underscores the significance of category design in achieving lasting recognition.
text_ko: 전설적인 사람은 그런 걸 하지 않았어요. 한 명도 없죠. 우리 모두 밥 말리(Bob Marley)가 누구인지 아는 반면, 세계에서 17위의 레게(Reggae) 뮤지션이나 밴드가 누구인지 아는 사람은 없어요.
text_zh: 没有人能做到这一点，传奇人物更是没有。我们都知道鲍勃·马利（Bob Marley）是谁，但我们却不知道世界上第十七位最伟大的雷鬼（reggae）音乐家或乐队是谁。
text_es: Nadie legendario hizo eso. Ni uno solo. Todos sabemos quién es Bob Marley. No sabemos quién es el 17º mejor músico o banda de reggae en el mundo.
key_sentence: Nobody legendary ever created new categories without distinction.

text: You either stay in your niche and get diminished over time, or you uplevel and you go to play for the whole enchilada.
speaker: Christopher Lochhead
context: Chris explains the choices available to companies once they find initial success in a niche market. He warns that staying confined to a niche can lead to stagnation, while expanding to capture the broader market ('the whole enchilada') can lead to significant growth. This highlights the importance of evolving beyond initial success to maintain relevance and competitiveness.
text_ko: 너는 네 틀 안에 머물면서 점점 작아지거나, 아니면 한 단계 업그레이드해서 모든 것을 다 잡으러 나가야 해요.
text_zh: 要么你固守自己的细分市场，随着时间的推移逐渐被边缘化，要么你提升自己，争取更大的市场份额。
text_es: Te quedas en tu nicho y te vas desvaneciendo con el tiempo, o te elevas y juegas por el todo.
key_sentence: Uplevel to play for the whole enchilada or get diminished over time.

text: Problems create categories, and you either have to A, solve a new problem, or B, reframe, name and claim an existing problem in a different way.
speaker: Christopher Lochhead
context: Chris discusses the fundamental relationship between problems and categories in business. He emphasizes that successful companies either solve a new problem or creatively reframe an existing one. This insight is crucial for entrepreneurs seeking to innovate and differentiate themselves in the market.
text_ko: 문제는 카테고리를 만들어줘요. 그래서 당신은 A, 새로운 문제를 해결하거나 B, 기존의 문제를 다른 방식으로 재정의하고 이름을 붙여야 해요.
text_zh: 问题创造了类别，你要么选择A，解决一个新问题，要么选择B，以不同的方式重新定义、命名并认领一个现有的问题。
text_es: Los problemas generan categorías, y tienes que A, resolver un nuevo problema, o B, replantear, nombrar y reivindicar un problema existente de una manera diferente.
key_sentence: Problems create categories; reframe, name and claim them differently.

text: Thinking about thinking is the most important kind of thinking.
speaker: Christopher Lochhead
context: Chris introduces the concept of 'thinking about thinking' as a foundational principle in category design. He suggests that entrepreneurs must reflect critically on their thought processes and assumptions to foster innovative thinking. This approach encourages breaking free from conventional mindsets to cultivate unique and impactful ideas.
text_ko: 생각하는 방법에 대해 생각하는 게 가장 중요한 생각이에요.
text_zh: 思考思考是最重要的思维方式。
text_es: Reflexionar sobre cómo pensamos es el tipo de pensamiento más importante.
key_sentence: Thinking about thinking is a foundational principle of important thought.

text: If you're lucky enough to make it to the top of a mountain, throw down a fucking rope.
speaker: Christopher Lochhead
context: Chris shares a personal motto that emphasizes the importance of helping others once you've achieved success. He underscores the value of mentorship and support, especially for those who face challenges. This message resonates with the theme of community and collaboration in the entrepreneurial journey.
text_ko: 산 정상에 오를 수 있다면, 꼭 밑에 있는 사람들에게 도움의 줄을 던져줘요.
text_zh: 如果你有幸登上了山顶，就要伸出援手。
text_es: Si tienes la suerte de llegar a la cima de una montaña, tiende una cuerda.
key_sentence: If you reach the top, throw down a rope.
